column5: I just got my refund for the 8-day fishing license. It took three months to get it. Here is the response I got back from my email asking for a refund. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, our current refund policy is as follows: * For purchases made between*December 3, 2019*(first available date for 2020 licence products) and*March 17, 2020*(date state of emergency was declared for Ontario), we will consider*refunds*for the following*non-expired products, and waive the $10.50 administrative fee: * 1-day and 8-day licences for all residencies if contacted before the effective date of the licences;1-year and 3-year fishing licences purchased by Canadian and*non-Canadian*residents (excludes Ontario*residents);Hunting licences and tags purchased by*non-ResidentsOutdoors Cards purchased with one of the above items * We are not able to extend validity dates on licence products. * We will submit for a refund of your 8-day license as you emailed us the day before expiry. Since I'm usually up there two or three times a year I buy the three year license. I called since this in my middle year, but they said no refund since I can't prove that I didn't use it before the border shut down or after if it ever does open in 2020.

I had also purchased annual non-resident in January for 3 trips this year. I sent an email to MNRF explaining purchase and inquiring if refunds were available. My license fee was refunded within a couple weeks. Email address: [email protected] Include in email: Outdoors card number
Just got my annual license refunded. It took 8 weeks but I found them to be very prompt, polite and accurate as to how long it would take.
Has anyone with a three year license received a refund for one year of it?
We don't need a license in Canada if we're 65?

Here's what I don' get, on waters that share Canadian and American borders you are not allowed to cross and go fishing when you don't touch land. Not sure what the Science is behind that decision. This spring on the Detroit River Canadian law enforcement was telling Americans to go back on the US side of the border giving them a warning the first time and telling them they could be ticketed. Haven't heard of US law enforcement doing the same but it may have happened just haven't heard about it. If anyone thinks you can sneak across and touch land on the Detroit or St. Clair rivers and not get caught I wouldn't try it, there are cameras everywhere monitored by law enforcement. Also, I don't know of a single fisherman who heads out on the water and crosses the border and wants to go on land when out fishing for the day, it wastes too much time. Back in the day prior to GPS, and those of us that remember the Loran C, it was very difficult to tell just where the border was when out on the water. Maybe if my GPS malfunctions I can use that as an excuse if I end up in Canadian water so that I can use my nonresident fishing license I purchased back in January. Another stupid restriction that makes no sense, but what do you expect from the Government.
Only if you are a resident.
There is still a border whether it's on land or water.
Thanks! That's what I was thinking. In Minnesota it used to be 65, but I guess we're living too long because it was changed to 90. I do get a free trout stamp though.

I lived in Michigan until 1984 and used to fish Lake St Clair a lot. Back then as long as we had a Canadian fishing license we were ok to fish anywhere on the lake. We could keep a Canadian limit of walleyes too.

I feel your pain but if this is the worst that you get shafted in your lifetime then you will have been a lucky man.

I seem to have a knack for doing the wrong thing when buying my license. This year I bought the season license early. A couple of years ago I just bought the week license and ended up going on 2 extra unplanned trips and bought 3 weekly licenses. In the grand scheme of things it is such a small percentage of the cost of the trip.
I'm assuming the license fees go to fish and game depts. I'd have to think that is a nice chunk of change for them. As far as the whole Ontario budget, it is peanuts.
Good luck on getting that donation back.

So I purchased my annual Ontario license in January for a trip to Rainy Lake scheduled for May. You all know how that went. I talked to the owner & rescheduled our trip for September. If that doesn't happen my annual license purchased as a non resident will go down the toilet unused. Do you think the Ontario License Dept might allow us non residents to use our 2020 license for 2021 since the border closing denied us use of our license we paid for in good faith? Might the Canadian government cut us some slack? What do you guys think?
All you can do is ask. Good luck!
Wish in one hand and you know in the other. Good luck.
